articles.headline: Bahrain Is Nervously Awaiting Report on Its Forgotten Revolt
articles.snippet: Bahrain’s king asked for an investigation of the country’s protests and crackdown, a complicated task with the goal of promoting healing and charting a way forward.
articles.abstract: Bahrain’s king asked for an investigation of the country’s protests and crackdown, a complicated task with the goal of promoting healing and charting a way forward.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — Bahrain’s forgotten revolt sometimes reads like the script for a film of international intrigue, where the truth remains elusive.

articles.headline: Separating You and Me? 4.74 Degrees
articles.snippet: Scientists at Facebook and the University of Milan reported on Monday that the average number of acquaintances separating any two people in the world is not six but 4.74.
articles.abstract: Scientists at Facebook and the University of Milan reported on Monday that the average number of acquaintances separating any two people in the world is not six but 4.74.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world is even smaller than you thought.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: As Layoffs Rise, Stock Buybacks Consume Cash
articles.snippet: As the nation seeks ways to create jobs, critics say many big companies are squandering resources on share repurchases at the expense of investing in future growth.
articles.abstract: As the nation seeks ways to create jobs, critics say many big companies are squandering resources on share repurchases at the expense of investing in future growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Pfizer cut its research budget this year and laid off 1,100 employees, it was not because the company needed to save money.

articles.headline: Screening Still a Pain at Airports, Fliers Say
articles.snippet: Some travelers are still bothered by the screening process at airports, and the airlines worry that the frustrations are contributing to a decline in air travel.
articles.abstract: Some travelers are still bothered by the screening process at airports, and the airlines worry that the frustrations are contributing to a decline in air travel.
articles.lead_paragraph: The lines will still be long and the screening still invasive at airport checkpoints this Thanksgiving.

articles.headline: For Deficit Panel, Failure Cuts Two Ways
articles.snippet: A sharp reduction in annual federal deficits, larger than anything contemplated by the special panel, could result from the latest Congressional failure to agree on a plan.
articles.abstract: A sharp reduction in annual federal deficits, larger than anything contemplated by the special panel, could result from the latest Congressional failure to agree on a plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The latest Congressional failure to agree on a plan for balancing the government’s books could yield a surprising result: a sharp reduction in annual federal deficits, larger than anything contemplated by the special panel that reached its fruitless finale on Monday.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: Pull of Family Reshapes U.S.-Cuban Relations
articles.snippet: Taking advantage of looser restrictions, younger Cuban-Americans who still have strong family ties to the island have been visiting and sending money with regularity.
articles.abstract: Taking advantage of looser restrictions, younger Cuban-Americans who still have strong family ties to the island have been visiting and sending money with regularity.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For two consecutive years, Stephanie Várcia, 11, a sixth grader here, has done something that was unimaginable five years ago. She has spent four weeks in Havana, playing hide-and-seek with her cousins and going to the beach with her aunts and uncles. When summer vacation ended, her mother flew out to bring her back to Miami.

articles.headline: Deal to Hasten Transition in Egypt Is Jeered at Protests
articles.snippet: The agreement on civilian rule struck by the Muslim Brotherhood and the military appeared unlikely to extinguish the resurgent protest movement.
articles.abstract: The agreement on civilian rule struck by the Muslim Brotherhood and the military appeared unlikely to extinguish the resurgent protest movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt careened through another day of crisis with no end in sight as hundreds of thousands of people occupying Tahrir Square jeered at a deal struck on Tuesday by the Muslim Brotherhood and the military that would speed up the transition to civilian rule on a timetable favoring the Islamist movement.
